photo.description: Agra Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage site located in Agra, India. The fort is also known as Lal Qila, Fort Rouge and Red Fort of Agra. It is about 2.5 km northwest of its much more famous sister monument, the Taj Mahal. The fort can be more accurately described as a walled palatial city. It is the most important fort in India. The great Mughals Babur, Humayun, Akbar, Jehangir, Shah Jahan and Aurangzeb lived here, and the country was governed from here. It contained the largest state treasury and mint. It was visited by foreign ambassadors, travellers and the highest dignitaries who participated in the making of history in India. [Wikipedia.org]
photo.title: Agra Fort

photo.description: Agra Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage site located in Agra, India. The fort is also known as Lal Qila, Fort Rouge and Red Fort of Agra. It is about 2.5 km northwest of its much more famous sister monument, the Taj Mahal. The fort can be more accurately described as a walled palatial city. It is the most important fort in India. The great Mughals Babur, Humayun, Akbar, Jehangir, Shah Jahan and Aurangzeb lived here, and the country was governed from here. It contained the largest state treasury and mint. It was visited by foreign ambassadors, travellers and the highest dignitaries who participated in the making of history in India. [Wikipedia.org]
photo.title: Agra Fort

photo.description: Agra Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage site located in Agra, India. The fort is also known as Lal Qila, Fort Rouge and Red Fort of Agra. It is about 2.5 km northwest of its much more famous sister monument, the Taj Mahal. The fort can be more accurately described as a walled palatial city. It is the most important fort in India. The great Mughals Babur, Humayun, Akbar, Jehangir, Shah Jahan and Aurangzeb lived here, and the country was governed from here. It contained the largest state treasury and mint. It was visited by foreign ambassadors, travellers and the highest dignitaries who participated in the making of history in India. [Wikipedia.org]
photo.title: Agra Fort

photo.description: Built entirely of marble by Shah Jahan in 1637, the Khas Mahal or the Private Palace demonstrates distinctive Islamic-Persian features. The enclosure has three pavilions overlooking the Yamuna, with a fountain opposite the central pavilion. The central pavilion an airy edifice, used by the emperor as a sleeping chamber has three arches on each side, five in front, and two turrets rising out of the roof. It overlooks the Angoori Bagh (grape garden). The Mahal is flanked by two golden (copper) pavilions, one with white marble and was supposedly decorated with gold leaf, while the other is made with red stone, which were meant for the prominent ladies of the harem. The Khaas Mahal provides the most successful example of painting on a white marble surface. [webindia123.com]
photo.title: The Khas Mahal - Agra Fort

photo.description: Built entirely of marble by Shah Jahan in 1637, the Khas Mahal or the Private Palace demonstrates distinctive Islamic-Persian features. The enclosure has three pavilions overlooking the Yamuna, with a fountain opposite the central pavilion. The central pavilion an airy edifice, used by the emperor as a sleeping chamber has three arches on each side, five in front, and two turrets rising out of the roof. It overlooks the Angoori Bagh (grape garden). The Mahal is flanked by two golden (copper) pavilions, one with white marble and was supposedly decorated with gold leaf, while the other is made with red stone, which were meant for the prominent ladies of the harem. The Khaas Mahal provides the most successful example of painting on a white marble surface. [webindia123.com]
photo.title: The Khas Mahal - Agra Fort

photo.description: "Shah Jahan" was held here in prison by his son, The legend tells that the day his wife died his hair turned completely white over night. From here he could watch her tomb the "Taj Mahal"

photo.description: Shah Jahan, builder of the Taj Mahal, was imprisoned by his son Aurangzeb in the Agra Fort for several years until his death. From his marble palace he had a view of the Taj Mahal, a memorial to his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal.
photo.tags: agra india mughal architecture unescoworldheritagesites 16thcentury
photo.title: Shah Jahan's marble prison

photo.description: Built of red sandstone, Agra Fort combines Hindu and Islamic architecture. Agra Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage site located in Agra near the famous Taj Mahal. This walled city/fort was fortified at various stages by the Mughal emporors Humayun, Akbar, Jehangir, Shah Jahan and Aurangzeb.
photo.tags: agra india mughal architecture unescoworldheritagesites 16thcentury
photo.title: Agra Fort

photo.title: Agra Fort

photo.description: Built of red sandstone, Agra Fort combines Hindu and Islamic architecture. Agra Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage site located in Agra near the famous Taj Mahal. This walled city/fort was fortified at various stages by the Mughal emporors Humayun, Akbar, Jehangir, Shah Jahan and Aurangzeb.
photo.tags: agra india mughal architecture unescoworldheritagesites 16thcentury
